message_1:
What is the value of the enthalpy change for the reaction of carbon monoxide (CO) with oxygen (O2) to form carbon dioxide (CO2) given the following balanced equation:

2CO(g) + O2(g) → 2CO2(g)

The enthalpies of formation for CO2, CO and O2 are -393.5 kJ/mol, -110.5 kJ/mol, and 0 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of CO2, and for the reactants, we have 2 moles of CO and 1 mole of O2.

ΔH_reaction = [2 × (-393.5 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (-110.5 kJ/mol) + 1 × (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_reaction = (-787 kJ) - (-221 kJ)

ΔH_reaction = -566 kJ

The enthalpy change for the reaction is -566 kJ.
